name: Database
overview:
This class allows you interact with Cloud Spanner.

First, install google-cloud with npm:

$ npm install --save google-cloud

If you are running your app on Google Compute Engine, you won't need to worry about supplying connection configuration options to google-cloudâ€” we figure that out for you.

However, if you're running your app elsewhere, you will need to provide project details to authenticate API requests.

Compute Engine

var gcloud = require('google-cloud'); var spanner = gcloud.spanner();

Elsewhere

var gcloud = require('google-cloud'); var spanner = gcloud.spanner({ projectId: 'grape-spaceship-123', keyFilename: '/path/to/keyfile.json' });

The full set of options which can be passed to google-cloud are outlined in our Authentication guide.

methods.name: Database
methods.description: Create a Database object to interact with a Cloud Spanner database.

examples.code:
var instance = spanner.instance('my-instance');
var database = instance.database('my-database');

params.name: name
params.description: • Name of the database.

params.name: options
params.description: • Session pool configuration options.

params.name: options.fail
params.description: • If set to true, an error will be thrown when there are no available sessions for a request. (Default: false)

params.name: options.max
params.description: • Maximum number of resources to create at any given time. (Default: 1)

params.name: options.maxIdle
params.description: • Maximum number of idle resources to keep in the pool at any given time.

params.name: options.min
params.description: • Minimum number of resources to keep in the pool at any given time. (Default: 0)

params.name: options.keepAlive
params.description: • How often to ping idle sessions, in minutes. Must be less than 1 hour.

params.name: options.writes
params.description: • Pre-allocate transactions for the number of sessions specified.

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: options
params.description: • See spanner/instance#createDatabase.

examples.code: database.exists(function(err, exists) {});

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: callback
params.description: • The callback function.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

params.name: callback.exists
params.description: • Whether the database exists or not.

methods.name: get
methods.description:
Get a database if it exists.

You may optionally use this to "get or create" an object by providing an object with autoCreate set to true. Any extra configuration that is normally required for the create method must be contained within this object as well.

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: options
params.description: • Configuration object.

params.name: options.autoCreate
params.description: • Automatically create the object if it does not exist. Default: false

methods.name: close
methods.description: Close the database connection and destroy all sessions associated with it.

params.name: callback
params.description: • The callback function.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: schema
params.description: • A DDL CREATE statement describing the table.

params.name: callback
params.description: • The callback function.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

params.name: callback.table
params.description: • The Table object.

params.name: callback.operation
params.description: • An operation object that can be used to check the status of the request.

params.name: callback.apiResponse
params.description: • The full API response.

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: callback
params.description: • The callback function.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

params.name: callback.apiResponse
params.description: • The full API response.

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: callback
params.description: • The callback function.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

params.name: callback.metadata
params.description: • The database's metadata.

params.name: callback.apiResponse
params.description: • The full API response.

methods.name: getSchema
methods.description: Get this database's schema as a list of formatted DDL statements.

examples.code: database.getSchema(function(err, statements, apiResponse) {});

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: callback
params.description: • The callback function.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

params.name: callback.statements
params.description: • An array of database DDL statements.

params.name: callback.apiResponse
params.description: • The full API response.

methods.name: run
methods.description: Execute a SQL statement on this database.

examples.caption: Rows are returned as an array of object arrays. Each object has a name and value property. To get a serialized object, call toJSON().
The SQL query string can contain parameter placeholders. A parameter placeholder consists of '@' followed by the parameter name.
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: query
params.description: • A SQL query or query object. See an ExecuteSqlRequest object.

params.name: options
params.description: • Transaction options.

params.name: options.exactStaleness
params.description: • Executes all reads at the timestamp that is exactStaleness old.

params.name: options.readTimestamp
params.description: • Execute all reads at the given timestamp.

params.name: options.returnTimestamp
params.description: • If true, returns the read timestamp.

params.name: options.strong
params.description: • Read at the timestamp where all previously committed transactions are visible.

params.name: callback
params.description: • The callback function.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

params.name: callback.rows
params.description: • Rows are returned as an array of objects. Each object has a name and value property. To get a serialized object, call toJSON().

methods.name: runStream
methods.description: Create a readable object stream to receive resulting rows from a SQL statement.

examples.caption: Rows are returned as an array of objects. Each object has a name and value property. To get a serialized object, call toJSON().
The SQL query string can contain parameter placeholders. A parameter placeholder consists of '@' followed by the parameter name.
If you anticipate many results, you can end a stream early to prevent unnecessary processing and API requests.

params.name: query
params.description: • A SQL query or query object. See an ExecuteSqlRequest object.

params.name: query.params
params.description: • A map of parameter name to values.

params.name: options
params.description: • Transaction options.

params.name: options.exactStaleness
params.description: • Executes all reads at the timestamp that is exactStaleness old.

params.name: options.readTimestamp
params.description: • Execute all reads at the given timestamp.

params.name: options.returnTimestamp
params.description: • If true, returns the read timestamp.

params.name: options.strong
params.description: • Read at the timestamp where all previously committed transactions are visible.

methods.name: runTransaction
methods.description:
A transaction in Cloud Spanner is a set of reads and writes that execute atomically at a single logical point in time across columns, rows, and tables in a database.

The callback you provide to this function will become the "run function". It will be executed with either an error or a spanner/transaction object. The Transaction object will let you run queries and queue mutations until you are ready to spanner/transaction#commit.

For a more complete listing of functionality available to a Transaction, see the spanner/transaction API documentation. For a general overview of transactions within Cloud Spanner, see Transactions from the official Cloud Spanner documentation.

examples.caption: For read-only transactions, use the transaction.end() function to release the transaction.
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: options
params.description: • Transaction options.

params.name: options.readOnly
params.description: • Specifies if the transaction is read-only.

params.name: options.exactStaleness
params.description: • Executes all reads at the timestamp that is exactStaleness old.

params.name: options.readTimestamp
params.description: • Execute all reads at the given timestamp.

params.name: options.returnTimestamp
params.description: • If true, returns the read timestamp.

params.name: options.strong
params.description: • Read at the timestamp where all previously committed transactions are visible.

params.name: runFn
params.description: • A function to execute in the context of a transaction.

params.name: runFn.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

params.name: runFn.transaction
params.description: • The Transaction object. The transaction has already been created, and is ready to be queried and committed against.

methods.name: table
methods.description: Get a reference to a Table object.

examples.code: var table = database.table('Singers');

params.name: name
params.description: • The name of the table.

methods.name: updateSchema
methods.description:
Update the schema of the database by creating/altering/dropping tables, columns, indexes, etc.

This method immediately responds with an Operation object. Register event handlers for the "error" and "complete" events to see how the operation finishes. Follow along with the examples below.

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: statements
params.description: • An array of database DDL statements, or an UpdateDatabaseDdlRequest object.

params.name: callback
params.description: • The callback function.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

params.name: callback.operation
params.description: • An operation object that can be used to check the status of the request.

params.name: callback.apiResponse
params.description: • The full API response.
